H0.text: Algae grows rapidly when excess nitrogen from fertilizer runoff enters a pond or lake ecosystem.

H1.text: Mutations occur gradually in fish is the effect that excess nitrogen carried by rainwater runoff into ponds and lakes has on organisms in a pond or lake ecosystem.

H2.text: Clam shells are slowly weakened by excess nitrogen that enters ponds and lakes through fertilizer runoff, leading to eutrophication and reduced shell integrity in aquatic organisms.

H3.text: Frogs adapt quickly to new food sources in a pond or lake ecosystem when excess nitrogen from fertilizer runoff is present.

A4.text: When an ecosystem experiences an increase in nutrients, primary producers reap the benefits first.

A5.text: Eutrophication is caused by excessive concentrations of nutrients, most commonly phosphates and nitrates.

A6.text: Algal blooms are the result of a nutrient, like nitrogen or phosphorus from various sources (for example fertilizer runoff or other forms of nutrient pollution), entering the aquatic system and causing excessive growth of algae.

A7.text: Algal blooms in freshwater systems are not always caused by human contamination and have been observed to occur naturally in both eutrophic and oligotrophic lakes.

A8.text: Excess nitrogen causes environmental problems such as harmful algal blooms, hypoxia, acid rain, nitrogen saturation in forests, and climate change.

A9.text: Excess nutrients have been summarized as potentially leading to excess growth of algae (harmful algal blooms).
